Column Comment.0: DEPENDENCY SET IDENTIFIER: A dependency set establishes a group of rulesthat will be processed as a unit. For example, a set may be created to quality controlwell locations using 3 rules. If RULE_ID 1 passes, proceed to RULE_ID 2. If itfails,proceed to RULE_ID 3.
Column Comment.1: RULE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a rule. Rules may be policies, practices,procedures or system business rules.
Column Comment.2: RULE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a related rule. Rules may be policies,practices, procedures or system business rules.
Column Comment.3: XREF OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique number added to the PK so that rulesmay be related to each other more than once, over time or for different businessreasons.
Column Comment.4: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.5: DESCRIPTION: Narrative description of the cross reference between business rules.
Column Comment.6: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.7: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.8: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.9: REMARK: A long description describing the information kept within the table in thePPDM schema.
Column Comment.10: CROSS REFERENCE CONDITION: The type of condition that must be met beforethis cross reference comes into effect, usually used when you need to create abranched or dependent sequence of events. For example, one row of data will statethat if the rule indicated as RULE_ID is successful, go to RULE_ID2. In another rowof data, you can state that if the first rule has failed, a different RULE_ID2 would be inforce.
Column Comment.11: PPDM RULE CROSS REFERENCE TYPE: The reason why a cross reference wascreated, such as an indication of a rule to be processed in the event that the first rulehas been processed and passed or failed. In this case, the reference XREF TYPEmay be RUN RULE ID2 if RULE ID passes (or fails). May also be used for rulemanagement, such as rule that replaces an old rule, rule that must be implementedbefore or after another rule a rule that is a component of another rule, or to build therelationships between policies, practices, procedures and business rules.
Column Comment.12: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.13: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.14: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.15: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.16: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.17: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.18: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.19: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
